General course objectives:
General course objectives
To give an in-depth understanding of modern scientific instrumentation for X- and Gamma-Ray Astronomy. This will include both the telescopes and the detector side.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
list the main steps in the evolution of astronomical observations
list the different methodologies of astronomical observations at different wavelengthsølgelængder
list other detection methods to e.g. gravitational waves
describe X-ray telescope designs and calculate the effective area and sensitivity of an X-ray telescope
explain the basic interaction between X-rays and matter
explain the parameters entering the figure of merit of an X-ray telescope and, based on this design, optimum reflective multilayer structures
explain the theory behind X-ray reflection in mirrors for X-ray telescopes and use this theory to calculate reflectance from multilayer structures
explain the different theories for the scattering of X-rays in surfaces and use these to calculate the scattering from simple surfaces
explain all the elements affecting the performance of an X-ray telescope
explain the principle and method of magnetron sputter deposition
use in-house 8 keV X-ray reflectometer for characterization of mirror coating performance
apply mathematical methods to data fitting and analysis, and simulate the performance of an X-ray telescope mirror.
Content: The course will start with a short introduction to telescopes in general, followed by an introduction to astronomical observations at different wavelengths, further focusing on high-energy telescopes. A theoretical introduction to X-ray telescopes covering reflection and scattering from mirrored surfaces and laboratory exercises on the production and characterization of X-ray mirrors. The course will also include the application of analytical and numerical methods used for data analysis and simulation of the scientific capabilities of realistic astronomical instruments.
